III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section Program statement
Description (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff members downgrade Youth A's emotions and feelings. They
make up rules specifically for Youth A because they do not want
her to go outside.
Investigation Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face with MDHHS
Worker at the facility on 6/9/2025. He reported Supervisor 3 has
been placed on administrative leave because of the allegations
and will not be working at the facility until this investigation is
completed or permission for her return is granted. He described
Supervisor 3 as working at the facility for some time and as a mild,
older staff.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face with the MDHHS Worker
at the facility on 6/9/2025. Youth A reported being in the program
for the past 8 months and having learned nothing during that time.
She reported there is nothing new she needs to learn and “this
place sucks”. She reported the staff are horrible but there are
some good things about the program. She reported staff do not
pass out consequences (such as going outside) the same which
causes her frustration. She provided an example of sometimes
losing her privileges for refusing to do chores and other times
doesn’t lose privileges when refusing to do chores. She reported
experiencing neglect at the facility and gave the following
examples: Staff don’t allow her to do things (nothing specific was
shared) until she completes something such as cleaning her room
or completing chores. She reported waking up late last week and
missing breakfast, so she made some toast, and staff told her to
hurry because she needs to be on time for school. She reported
because she slept in, she didn’t have time to finish her chores,
therefore she was marked down in points which she believes is
the staff’s way of “getting” her. Youth A also reported Supervisor 1
has told Youth A to “shut up” and kicked Youth A in the right leg.
Youth A reported not feeling safe at the facility and having to sleep
2

with one eye open at all times. Youth A believes she is not doing
anything wrong, and staff are not respecting Youth A’s
boundaries. Youth A is hoping to move into Independent living or
Adult Foster Care soon.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face with MDHHS Worker
at the facility on 6/9/2025. She reported filling in as Youth A’s
therapist since the primary therapist is on vacation. She reported
“pulling” Youth A for an individual therapy session on 6/5/25 and
Youth A stated staff are not allowing Youth A to leave the building.
Therapist reported Youth A indicated being on a level that would
allow Youth A to go outside but being restricted from going outside
by staff because staff informed Youth A that because of a verbal
conflict, Youth A was being restricted. Youth A said Youth A was
in an argument with another youth (didn’t identify who) but doesn’t
know what the conflict was about.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face with MDHHS Worker at
the facility on 6/9/2025. Youth C reported this program is one of
the “better” programs and Youth C believes Youth C is well taken
care of in the program. However, Youth C reported that Youth C is
being held against Youth C’s will. Youth C reported not liking
Youth B because Youth B is autistic and Youth B makes the
program unsafe. Youth C also reported feeling safe overall in the
program. Youth C reported staff are “good overall” but don’t aways
enforce the consequences the same for each youth (unable to
provide a specific example).
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face with MDHHS Worker at
the facility on 6/9/2025. Youth B reported sometimes staff are not
nice but was unable to provide specific examples of not being nice
other than arguments at times. Youth B reported making threats
about hitting others but never acted on these threats which is
“typical teenage stuff”. Youth B reported on 6/5/25, Supervisor 1,
Supervisor 3, Youth A, Youth B, and two other staff were present
(unable to recall who these other staff were), when Youth A was
escalated and “started saying things”. Youth B reported
Supervisor 3 said “beat your ass”. Youth B reported feeling safe at
the facility and enjoying placement in the program.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed face-to-face with the MDHHS
Worker at the facility on 6/9/2025. She described Youth A as
having “poor boundaries with a need for lots of redirection”.
Supervisor 3 reported Youth A was not allowed outside because
Youth A had lost that privilege for displaying poor boundaries and
needed to stay inside to have Youth A’s individual therapy
3

session. Supervisor 3 reported Youth A stated, “you will see what I
will do to you now” in response to Supervisor 3 informing Youth A
about the restriction of going outside. Supervisor 3 reported Youth
A made a similar statement of “seeing what will happen to you” to
Supervisor 1 and Youth A stated, “going to put this business out in
the street”. She reported staff have addressed this type of
behavior and the lack of appropriate boundaries Youth A
continues to display. She reported Youth A has a habit of walking
up to staff and hugging staff while telling staff Youth A loves the
staff. Supervisor 3 denied saying “beat your ass” as suggested by
Youth B.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face with MDHHS
Worker at the facility on 6/9/2025. She described Youth A as
struggling with boundary issues daily and being redirected by staff
throughout the day about Youth A’s boundary issues. She
described Youth A as attention seeking which comes from Youth
A’s past trauma. Supervisor 1 reported having a good relationship
with Youth A and having skills to work with youth having a
Borderline Personality Disorder such as Youth A is displaying.
She reported over the past few months Youth A has struggled
even more, and she believes it is tied to Youth A’s upcoming
placement to Independent Living. She reported there was no
disagreement with Youth A over Youth A’s points and that Youth A
said Youth A understood the reason for the low points. The topic
of the group (6/5/25) was to identify how a youth is doing in the
program, and Supervisor 1 reported Youth A stated Youth A
needs to work on more things. Supervisor 1 reported this was not
documented in any type of group note. Regarding Youth A saying
staff are unfair and want her to fail, Supervisor 1 reported never
saying to any youth to hit another youth or threaten another youth.
Regarding the allegation that Supervisor 3 said “beat your ass”
with Youth A during a meeting on 6/5/25, Supervisor 1 denied
Supervisor 3 made that statement and also denied telling Youth A
to shut up.
Documents Reviewed:
Email from MDHHS Worker dated 6/10/25. MDHHS Worker
stated Supervisor 3 can return to having contact with Youth A and
other youth since there is no evidence that Supervisor 3 caused
any physical injury to Youth A. She states it is important that
Supervisor 3 understand during her 1:1 meeting that Supervisor 3
understands the cautions of continuing contact with Youth A and
that joking or slapping Youth A’s hand is inappropriate. MDHHS
Worker approved the safety plan.
4

Wedgwood Christian Services Riebel rules and Expectations
General house rules without a date. This document outlines the
rules for the unit where Youth A is lodged. Rule number 12 states
youth are not allowed in the staff office. The level system is
outlined on this document and daily point sheets are used to
measure youth’s success and areas in need of improvement. The
facility will use a calculated weekly number for each youth and
changes to the youth’s level will occur on Thursdays. There are
six levels outlined with the Orientation level at the beginning. It is
documented that youth can move up to the next level after the
orientation level by building trust with staff and their therapist,
avoiding peer negativity, not engaging in AWOL, and no negative
talk or suspicious behavior. Level 1 can last for 1 week but the
time on this level is determined by the youth’s therapist and staff.
A youth can be placed on level 1 for unsafe, aggressive, violent,
or sexually inappropriate behaviors. Other reasons are
documented as including AWOL, hurting someone or threatening
aggression, sexual boundary violations, breaking something on
purpose, and significantly unsafe contraband. A youth can move
to level 2 or be removed from level 1 after an assessment by their
therapist and staff and found to be safe. Level 2 is documented as
the youth needing more work on processing basic house and
program expectations. To move to the next level, it is documented
that youth must accept feedback and redirection from staff, show
educational effort, positive participation in all activities such as
group, therapy, programming, show improvement in handling
frustration and anger, following routines such as chores and
bedroom cleaning, and maintaining a positive attitude while
avoiding negative peer interaction. Level 3 is documented as the
youth is doing well in general and following rules and
programming expectations on a consistent basis. Youth are also
expected to model program values with a weekly point average of
at least 2.8. It is documented youth must display the ability to
follow staff’s direction, be invested in schooling, display positive
leadership, use proper coping skills, complete daily routines
successfully, display appropriate communication, demonstrate
knowledge and value for programming, and maintain level 3 for
four weeks consecutively. Youth are also expected to write an
essay explaining why they are ready to move to level 4. Level 4 is
for youth that are excelling in the program and consistently
showing investment in treatment. They will demonstrate positive
leadership abilities and attitude. They need very little redirection
from staff and hold peers accountable in a positive consistent
manner. The last level is the transition level in which the youth are
just about ready to be discharged from this program into a less
5

secure program. In the section titled “Jobs/Chores general
housekeeping” it is documented that if a youth fails to complete
their room and/or job, they may not use privileges that day which
included they are not allowed to go off grounds or have free time
outside.
HR file for Supervisor 1 was reviewed. Documentation indicates
Supervisor 1 was hired on 8/8/04 and the documented disciplinary
action in the file is dated 1/31/23. This action involves a “growth
plan” for lack of staff competency, effective communication, and
training. Supervisor 1 is also up to date on required trainings.
HR file for Supervisor 3 was reviewed. Documentation indicates
Supervisor 3 was hired on 1/17/22 and the disciplinary action
documented in the file involves a “growth plan dated 2/13/23” for
lack of staff competency, effective communication, and training.
Supervisor 3 is also up to date on her required trainings.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as evidenced by interviews with
staff, and youth and documents reviewed. Evidence does not
support the allegations that Youth A is being mistreated and
having privileges removed. Youth A seems to present with
struggles with relationships and processing Youth A’s own
emotions and perceptions of the environment.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & R 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section Rule 158. (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow
Description written policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a youth
on any part of their body.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff members and other residents are threatening Youth A and
physically abusing her. On 6/2/25, Supervisor 3 smacked Youth A
on her right hand. This resulted in a red mark for a few hours.
There is no red mark today. A couple weeks ago, Supervisor 1
kicked Youth A in her leg. There is still a bruise today from being
kicked. She is threatened by both staff and other residents. Youth
A feels unsafe due to physical abuse from other residents and
staff members.
6

Investigation Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face with MDHHS
Worker at the facility on 6/9/2025. He reported Supervisor 3 has
been placed on administrative leave because of the allegations
and will not be working at the facility until this investigation is
completed or permission for her return is granted. He described
Supervisor 3 as working at the facility for some time and is a mild
older staff. He reported the allegations appear to have taken place
at lunchtime on 6/1/25 or 6/2/25 as reported by Youth A. He
reported requesting the video recording for those days and times
but has yet to receive the footage. Administrator 1 will develop a
safety plan once the video recording is reviewed but Supervisor 3
is not currently working at the facility. Administrator 1 reported
video footage is available for only 30 days before it is erased. The
allegations with Supervisor 1 were beyond 30 days.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face with MDHHS Worker at
the facility on 6/9/2025. Youth A was asked for more details
about the event outlined in the allegations involving Supervisor 3.
She reported after school she was doing her chore of wiping off
the table following dinner and observed Supervisor 3’s phone on
the table. She reported picking up the phone and handing it to
Supervisor 3. Supervisor 3 then snatched it from Youth A’s hand
and used her other hand to strike Youth A in the face. Youth A
reported laughing it off but later realized the hit left a handprint on
Youth A’s hand. Youth A reported telling Supervisor 3 later in the
day that Supervisor 3 had hit Youth A on the hand, but Supervisor
3 said your joking. Youth A reported responding with “I’m not
joking”. Youth A reported the mark on her hand lasted a “couple of
days”. She denied there were witnesses to the incident. When
asked about the allegations of Supervisor 1 kicking Youth A in the
leg, Youth A wanted to report a restraint she experienced
approximately 2 months ago involving Supervisor 1. Youth A
reported being restrained after trying to attack Supervisor 1 after
Supervisor 1 removed Youth A from class for passing a note.
Youth A reported this was unfair because she was trying to get
her education and went into a trauma cycle, attacking Supervisor
1. Regarding the allegations of Supervisor 1 kicking Youth A in the
leg, Youth A reported a couple of days ago Supervisor 1 kicked
Youth A in the right leg. Youth A reported getting into an argument
with Supervisor 1 because Youth A didn’t reach Youth A’s level
and believed it to be unfair. Youth A reported Supervisor 1 said
Youth A didn’t deserve to make the level and disagreed with
Youth A. Youth A also reported Supervisor 1 told Youth A to “shut
up” and kicked Youth A in the right leg. Youth A reported not
showing the bruising to nursing.
7

Supervisor 1 was interviewed face-to-face with MDHHS
Worker at the facility on 6/9/2025. She described Youth A as
attention seeking which comes from Youth A’s past trauma.
Supervisor 1 reported having a good relationship with Youth A and
having skills to work with youth having a Borderline Personality
Disorder such as Youth A is displaying. She reported a few
months ago Youth A claimed Supervisor 1 tried to choke Youth A,
but Supervisor 1 denied this allegation. She reported Youth A was
attacking her in the doorway of the office when Supervisor 1 put
up her hands to block Youth A’s punches and brushed Youth A’s
neck with her hand. This is the incident (restraint for attacking
Supervisor 1) Youth A wanted to talk about when asked about
being kicked by Supervisor 1. She reported Youth A went to the
floor after the restraint was initiated and tried to kick staff while
laying on the floor. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A came to
Supervisor 1 a couple of days later to apologize for claiming
Supervisor 1 had tried to choke Youth A. Supervisor 1 reported
being told by Foster Care Worker that staff should not be alone
with Youth A because Youth A has a history of making false
complaints against others. Supervisor 1 denied kicking Youth A
and any other youth. She reported there was no disagreement
with Youth A over Youth A’s points and that Youth A said Youth A
understood the reason for the low points. The topic of the group
(6/5/25) was to identify how a youth is doing in the program, and
Supervisor 1 reported Youth A stated Youth A needs to work on
more things. Supervisor 1 reported this was not documented in
any type of group note. Regarding Youth A saying staff are unfair
and want her to fail, Supervisor 1 reported never saying to any
youth to hit another youth or threaten another youth.
Administrator 3 was interviewed face-to-face with the MDHHS
Worker at the facility on 6/9/2025. Administrator 3 works as the
Coordinator of nursing administration services for the facility. She
reported talking with Youth A and Therapist on 6/5/25 when Youth
A said Youth A was unhappy with staff threatening to hit youth
(Administrator 3 had no more details about this allegation). Youth
A informed Administrator 3 that Youth A had already informed
Therapist about this allegation.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face with the MDHHS Worker
at the facility on 6/9/2025. Youth B reported feeling safe at the
facility and enjoying placement in the program. Youth B reported
sometimes staff are not nice but was unable to provide specific
examples of not being nice other than arguments at times. Youth
B reported making threats about hitting others but never acted on
these threats which is “typical teenage stuff”. Youth B reported
8

staff have never threatened to hit her or others and staff have
never been physical with Youth B. Youth B reported on 6/5/25,
Supervisor 1, Supervisor 3, Youth A, Youth B, and two other staff
were present (unable to recall who these other staff were), when
Youth A was escalated and “started saying things”. Youth B
reported Supervisor 3 said “beat your ass” and Youth A said
Youth A would file a compliance form, but Youth B doesn’t know if
Youth A did.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face with MDHHS Worker at
the facility on 6/9/2025. Youth C reported never observing staff
being inappropriate with a youth such as hitting, kicking, or
threatening.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face with MDHHS Worker at
the facility on 6/9/2025. Youth D reported her experience in the
program has been positive and Youth D has never seen a staff
become physical with a youth. Youth D reported there is nothing
wrong on the unit and overall, the program is helpful. Youth D
reported staff never make threats towards youth and will say
“please remove your hands off me” if a youth is touching a staff.
Staff will also say “calm down and let’s talk about it” if a youth is
upset. Youth D reported staff try to do their best and Youth D feels
safe in the program.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed face-to-face with MDHHS
Worker at the facility on 6/9/2025. Regarding the situation that
resulted in the restraint a few months prior, Supervisor 3 reported
Youth A was taken out of class because Youth A was picking up
notes from a male youth that Youth A liked from a different unit
and staff wanted to address the issue with Youth A. Regarding
the allegation of Supervisor 3 hitting Youth A’s hand, Supervisor 3
reported Youth A was cleaning the table and brought Supervisor
3’s phone to Supervisor 3 who took the phone from Youth A.
Supervisor 3 reported Youth A jokingly said “I’m going to fight you”
but Supervisor 3 didn’t respond. She reported not hitting or
slapping Youth A’s hand, but she may have brushed Youth A’s
hand when taking the phone from Youth A. She reported if she
had hit Youth A’s hand, Youth A would have made a big deal of
being hit. Supervisor 3 reported Youth A had a habit of joking with
Supervisor 3 and fighting with Supervisor 3. Regarding the report
by Youth B, Supervisor denied anyone or herself making a
threatening statement to hit or “kick your ass” to Youth B.
Supervisor 3 reported staff do not change rules on youth and
youth are given a rule book upon entry to the program which staff
9

follow. She reported again, Youth A has a habit of trying to get
staff fired if staff enforce a consequence with Youth A.
Supervisor 4 was interviewed via phone on 7/11/2025. He
reported being present during the situation described in the
allegation of Supervisor 1 kicking Youth A in the leg. He reported
helping with the restraint of Youth A at that time and never
witnessed or believed Supervisor 1 had kicked or attempted to
kick Youth A. Supervisor 4 reported when the standing restraint
began, Youth A dropped Youth A’s weight and went to the floor.
Staff disengaged and Youth A attempted to kick Supervisor 1.
Video Review:
A review of the 6/1/25 video recording was conducted. This video
takes place at lunch time and Youth A and Supervisor 3 are
observed in the video. The other youth in the unit are sitting at the
lunch table with Youth A and Supervisor 3. After finishing lunch,
Youth A begins to clean off the table by wiping the table down and
Supervisor 3 is observed sitting at the end of the table. At no time
is there physical contact between them and Youth A appears to go
out of the way (walking behind Supervisor 3) to keep distance
from Supervisor 3. There is no phone visible in the video and at no
time does Supervisor 3 strike or hit Youth A’s hand or any other
part of Youth A’s person.
A review of the 6/2/25 video recording was conducted. As with the
6/1/25 video recording, the view of the table show Youth A, all
youth in unit, and Supervisor 3 sitting at the table eating lunch.
Following lunch, Youth A began to clear and wipe the table. At no
time does Youth A make contact with Supervisor 3 and no phone
is observed in the video. Youth A and Supervisor 3 do not appear
to have any conversation between them and there is no physical
contact between them. Supervisor 3 does not hit or strike Youth A
during the video.
Documents Reviewed:
Email from Administrator 1 dated 6/9/25. He reported reviewing
video recording for 6/1/25 from 11:30 am to 12:45 pm with a view
of the milieu area. Youth A is documented as being in the milieu
with Supervisor 3 when there is limited interaction between them.
He reported at no time does Youth A engage with Supervisor 3
and leaves the milieu without incident.
10

Email from Administrator 1 dated 6/9/25. Administrator 1
updates the facility action taken with Supervisor 3 during this
investigation. Supervisor 3 has been taken off rotation and will not
have youth contact until approved by MDHHS Worker. Supervisor
3 will be allowed to perform administration day tasks which include
onboarding and training new employees. Supervisor 3 will engage
in a discussion with administration about the need to be more
aware of the heightened sensitivity of youth. A focus of removing
opportunities for youth to be alone with staff or in any way unable
to provide corroboration for any potential future claims that may be
made. This action will be documented in leadership emails. Prior
to Supervisor 3’s return to service will include a 1:1 meeting with
her direct supervisor to remind Supervisor 3 of heightened
boundaries with concerned youth including above reasonable and
prudent parent standards.
Email from Administrator 1 dated 6/10/25. He reported
reviewing the video recording for 6/2/25 from 11:30 am to 12:45
pm. Youth A is documented as entering the milieu at
approximately 12:00 pm and presents with “baseline” behaviors.
Supervisor 3 is on shift helping other staff and youth preparing
lunch. Youth A is observed sitting in her seat at the table and
engages in positive interactions with other youth and staff.
Supervisor 3 then sits at the head of the table and engages with
the other staff and youth. He reported that after lunch, Youth A
begins the chore of cleaning the table by wiping down the table.
Youth A then lines up to go back to class and leaves the room. He
reported at no time is Youth A and Supervisor 3 in close proximity
and no physical contact occurred between them.
Email from Administrator 1 dated 6/12/25 regarding an email
from Program Manager. The title of Administrator 1’s email is
evidence of collaboration with support departments for boundaries
with Youth A. Program Manager states because of the increased
stress and relational reactivity associated with Youth A, staff are
encouraged to not be alone with Youth A especially outside of
camera monitored spaces. She encourages staff to communicate
encouragement and validate Youth A’s presence however, during
a walk or if Youth A askes to speak to staff, staff are to redirect
Youth A to Youth A’s direct unit staff or Therapist who have clear
directives for interaction with Youth A. Staff are to remind Youth A
that Youth A possesses coping skills and to use Youth A’s safety
plan to remain calm. Staff are encouraged when on the unit to join
activities that are occurring rather than to spend 1:1 time with
Youth A.
11

Email from Administrator 1 dated 6/12/25 regarding an email
from Program Manager. The title of this email is the safety plan
that was communicated via email to the treatment team. It is
stated that this email was reviewed in the team meeting 6/12/25
and a sign-in log was provided to document participation. It is also
stated that Supervisor 3 met with Supervisor 1 for supervision and
reviewed a relational best practice plan. The second part of this
email from Program Manager addresses the following. She notes
that Youth A’s current level of sensitivity, poor boundaries, and
unhealthy coping skills have resulted in putting in place a safety
plan to protect Youth A and staff engaged in Youth A’s treatment.
Staff are to following the safety plan outlined below.
• Continue to provide exceptional customer service and
treatment for Youth A. Remaining in a space of positive
regard, dignity, and respect at all times.
• Staff will not be 1:1 in Youth A’s room. When conducting
bed checks or opening a door for her, staff will not linger or
engage in dialogue in the hallway space. Staff will inform
another staff that they are about to conduct a bed check or
safety check whenever able.
• When engaging with Youth A, please have heightened
boundaries. Playful/joking conversations and actions
should be avoided due to her misinterpretation or skewed
retelling of the interaction by Youth A.
• It remains our responsibility to transport Youth A to medical
appointments. When we are able, a preferred staff will take
Youth A to the appointment and shift supervisor, or peer
staff will complete a mental health/safety check-in before
and after the appointment. Ensuring that Youth A is in a
positive and safe space to attend the appointment prior to
leaving and checking in when she returns to see if the
appointment went well. Whenever possible a second pair of
eyes will observe Youth A as she leaves and returns from
appointments to create accountability, this includes any one
on her treatment team.
• Staff will provide thorough documentation and detail in
observation notes and fill-in reports (SER if needed)
regarding Youth A’s behaviors with poor boundaries,
attention seeking behaviors, and unhealthy coping skills
12

• Staff will gently redirect Youth A when non-Riebel team
visitors and supports enter the unit and Youth A
approaches, asking to talk with them. Staff will redirect
Youth A back to the activity she was previously doing,
allowing the support staff the space and time to complete
the task they need to do. Wedgwood residential support
staff will be informed of the goal to reduce triangulation and
trauma reenactment by being mindful of physical and
emotional boundaries with Youth A.
Email from Administrator 1 dated 6/12/25 regarding an update
on video review. He states the camera footage from February is
not available because the recording only lasts 30 days. He
reported camera footage from 6/5/25 has no evidence of a
disagreement between Youth A, Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 3
and there is no video or other evidence of Supervisor 1 kicking
Youth A.
Email from Administrator 1 dated 6/12/25. He reports reviewing
the 6/1/25 video around 1:45 pm after Program Manager asked
Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 3 again about the incident time
frame. He reports “at no time during this period do I see any cell
phone left unattended, being handled by Youth A, or any hitting
occur”. Administrator 1 reports that without further details or a
specific date and time, there doesn’t appear to be any evidence to
support the allegations made by Youth A in the video footage
reviewed.
Email from Administrator 1 dated 6/13/25. He reported
reviewing the 6/5/25 video footage and finding at no time is there
any form of disagreement between Supervisor 1 and Youth A nor
any kicking of Youth A by Supervisor 1 found on the recording.
Wedgwood Christian Services Behavior Management Report
dated 2/6/25 at 1:10 pm for Youth A. This is the incident report
for the physical restraint in the allegation of Supervisor 1 kicking
Youth A after an argument in the doorway of Supervisor 1’s office.
It is documented that Youth A went from the classroom to
Supervisor 1’s office to process the issue of Youth A passing
notes to a male youth in the school. Youth A is documented as
presenting a negative attitude and began swearing and making
threats toward staff when confronted on Youth A’s behaviors.
Supervisor 1 asked to take a break and then resume the
conversation once Youth A could use a more respectful tone.
13
